data.text: Benoît Cœuré: Libra has undoubtedly been a wake-up call for central banks to strengthen their efforts to improve existing payment systems. 6/8
Benoît Cœuré: “Stablecoinisation” would potentially relegate key public policies to private payment system providers – an outcome which citizens clearly cannot accept. 5/8
Benoît Cœuré: Stablecoin initiatives can make international payments cheaper and faster and support financial inclusion, but they raise formidable regulatory and systemic concerns. 4/8
Benoît Cœuré: It is probably easier to connect a new currency to an existing network than to build a new network on an existing currency. This is what “stablecoin” initiatives are about. 3/8
Benoît Cœuré: Globalisation and growing online services support consumer demand for fast and cheap cross-border payments. 2/8

(THREAD) In his speech at the Banque Centrale du Luxembourg-Toulouse School of Economics conference, Benoît Cœuré spoke about how digitalisation may change the future of the international financial system. Read on for more. 1/8 https://t.co/evuIet0tex
Speech Andrea Enria: Post-crisis repair and the profitability malady https://t.co/0JCJ5ao6St
Working paper: Stock price cycles and business cycles https://t.co/r9Kb9vIaeP

Lane: The ECB’s mandate for price stability is unconditional, and the Governing Council is unwavering in its commitment to achieve its inflation aim. Read the full speech here https://t.co/mn2XVUJAhN

Lane: The two-tier system for reserve remuneration – which will take effect on 30 October 2019 – supports the bank-based transmission mechanism, as it will mitigate the adverse side effects of negative interest rates on banks.

Lane: Stating clearly our commitment to symmetry is important, since the formulation of our aim – “below, but close to, 2 percent” – risks being misunderstood, particularly in an environment of falling inflation expectations.
Lane: We judge that, if needed, we can further lower the deposit facility rate and, with it, the overnight money market rate.
Lane: We are confident that the envisaged purchase volumes will be consistent with the current parameters of the APP for an extended period of time.
Lane: Additional net asset purchases and, by implication, the revised reinvestment horizon reinforce the accommodative impact of our policy rates in several ways: https://t.co/glgKOlc9Db

Lane: The Governing Council was confronted with a more extended slowdown than previously anticipated. The case for a monetary policy response was clear. A comprehensive package of measures was judged to be most effective way to support the convergence of inflation to our aim. https://t.co/xDZsRCeaws

Lane: The slowdown in manufacturing has an asymmetric effect across member countries and different sectors. Comparing national business climate indicators shows a relatively pronounced deterioration of sentiment in Germany. https://t.co/LhbTe21jl9

Lane: This slowdown is mainly due to external developments. While domestic demand is resilient, persistent uncertainties related to protectionist policies and geopolitical factors are taking a toll on economic sentiment and clearly weighing on the euro area manufacturing sector.

[THREAD] In a speech in London, ECB Chief Economist Philip R. Lane spoke about last week’s monetary policy decisions. He underlined that the measures announced are broad-based and designed to complement each other in providing monetary stimulus. https://t.co/QZJMV6VeFC
Speech Philip R. Lane: Reflections on monetary policy https://t.co/mn2XVUJAhN

All benchmark rates should have a fallback rate that can be used if the main rate is not available. The working group on risk-free rates is looking for an administrator for a benchmark rate that could serve as fallback to EURIBOR. More information https://t.co/rOgFhy908s https://t.co/m3ZWf6Zotq

Press release: ECB announces changes to new targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III) https://t.co/rD3Gu4to1z
Draghi: Giving money to people in whatever form is a fiscal policy task, not a monetary policy task
Draghi: Negative rates will not provoke the collapse of the financial system
Draghi: The necessity to adjust bank business models to changes in technology is something more compelling than being angry about negative rates
Draghi: Symmetry means we react to inflation below our aim with same strength as to inflation above our aim

Draghi: We are very concerned about the pension industry and related services. Negative rates are necessary instruments of monetary policy. It has created a lot of positive effects. How do we speed up these effects so that interest rates can go up? The answer is fiscal policy.
Draghi: We should be extremely humble in making recommendations to governments
Draghi: We still think that the probability of a recession in the euro area is small, but it has gone up
Draghi: The answer to many of the side effects is not to change our policy but respond with macroprudential policies
Draghi: We should be aware of the side effects of our monetary policy and we are closely monitoring all these effects
Draghi: We will never pursue competitive devaluation in line with the agreement among G20 members
Draghi: The European economy is a bank-based economy and we want to protect the transmission of our monetary policy through the lending channel. That's the philosophy of the measures we took today.
Draghi: We have a mandate, we pursue price stability and we don't target exchange rates. Period.
Draghi: There was no appetite to discuss limits, because we have the headroom to go on for quite some time without raising the discussion about limits
Draghi: The package is quite powerful both in the short run and in the long run
Draghi: The consensus was so broad that there was no need to take a vote, there was a clear majority
Draghi: There was unanimity that fiscal policy should become the main instrument
Draghi: There were three elements behind the decision: a protracted slowdown in the economy, the persistence of downside risks in global trade, the downward revision in inflation projections
Draghi: Improving the functioning of Economic and Monetary Union remains a priority
Draghi: In view of the weakening economic outlook and the continued prominence of downside risks, governments with fiscal space should act in an effective and timely manner
Introductory statement of Mario Draghi to the press conference: https://t.co/rwdwmYY1uy
Draghi introduces the GDP and inflation outlook for the euro area https://t.co/ROiKrLQazO

Incoming information since the last Governing Council meeting indicates a more protracted weakness of the euro area economy, the persistence of prominent downside risks and muted inflationary pressures
Draghi: We stand ready to adjust all of our instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards our aim in a sustained manner, in line with our commitment to symmetry
Draghi: The Governing Council reiterated the need for a highly accommodative stance of monetary policy for a prolonged period of time

Draghi: We decided to introduce a two-tier system for reserve remuneration in which part of banks’ holdings of excess liquidity will be exempt from the negative deposit facility rate to support the bank-based transmission of monetary policy
Draghi: The maturity of the TLTRO III operations will be extended from two to three years

Draghi: For banks whose eligible net lending exceeds a benchmark, the rate applied in TLTRO III operations will be lower, and can be as low as the average interest rate on the deposit facility prevailing over the life of the operation

Draghi: The interest rate in each operation of the TLTRO III will now be set at the level of the average rate applied in the Eurosystem’s main refinancing operations over the life of the respective TLTRO

Draghi: We decided to change the modalities of the TLTRO III to preserve favourable bank lending conditions, ensure the smooth transmission of monetary policy and further support the accommodative stance of monetary policy

Draghi: We intend to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when we start raising the key ECB interest rates

Draghi: We expect the net asset purchases to run for as long as necessary to reinforce the accommodative impact of our policy rates, and to end shortly before we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Draghi: We decided to restart net purchases under the APP at a monthly pace of €20 billion as from 1 November
Draghi: We now expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at their present or lower levels until we have seen the inflation outlook robustly converge to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2%
Draghi: The interest rate on the main refinancing operations and the rate on the marginal lending facility will remain unchanged at their current levels of 0.00% and 0.25% respectively
Draghi: We decided to lower the interest rate on the deposit facility by 10 basis points to -0.50%
